name.text: Michelson Interferometer: Fringe Spacing and Source Separation

questiontext.text: In a Michelson Interferometer, two dark fringes are spaced 1 inch apart (measured center-to-center). These fringes are observed on a screen placed 60 cm away from the lens. If the wavelength of the laser used is 632 nm, determine the separation between the two point sources (formed by the He-Ne laser images). Use the relationship: \(\sin(\theta) - \sin(-\theta) = \frac{\lambda}{\Lambda}\) and approximate \(\tan(\theta) \approx \sin(\theta)\) for the easy solution. Verify whether the results from the exact and approximate methods are nearly identical.

feedback.text:
**Hard Solution:**
1. Use the grating equation: \(\sin(\theta_{out}) - \sin(\theta_{in}) = \frac{\lambda}{\Lambda}\). We will assume \(\theta_{in} = 0\) for simplicity.
2. Solve for \(\theta_{out}\) \(\Lambda = .0254\) \( \lambda = 632 \cdot 10^{-9}\) \(\theta_{out} = \arcsin(\frac{\lambda}{\Lambda})\).
3. Convert angle to distance using tangent: \(.6\cdot \tan\theta \approx 15 \mu \).
**Easy Solution:**
1. Approximate \(\tan(\theta) \approx \sin(\theta)\) for small angles.
2. \(.6\cdot \frac{\lambda}{\Lambda} \approx 15 \mu\).
